prevtext.line: The fusion of a <ahref>boron</ahref> nucleus with a <ahref>proton</ahref> (<ahref>hydrogen</ahref> ion) produces slow-moving <ahref>helium</ahref> particles but no <ahref>neutron</ahref>s or radioactive waste.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.zmescience.com/science/hydrogen-boron-laser-fusion-15122017|title=Functional hydrogen-boron fusion could be here "within the next decade", powered by huge lasers|last=|first=|date=2017-12-15|work=ZME Science|access-date=2017-12-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> One method of producing proton-boron fusion uses one laser to create a <ahref>boron-11</ahref> <ahref>plasma (physics)|plasma</ahref> and another to create a stream of <ahref>proton</ahref>s that smash into the plasma. The laser-generated proton beam produces a tenfold increase of boron fusion because protons and boron nuclei collide directly. Earlier methods used a solid boron target, "protected" by its <ahref>electron</ahref>s, which reduced the fusion rate.<ref name="nat1013">{{Cite journal|date=2013|title=Two-laser boron fusion lights the way to radiation-free energy|journal=Nature|doi=10.1038/nature.2013.13914|last1=Cowen|first1=R.}}</ref>
